instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good‚Äù and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP3V3S3_EN: What is PP3V3S3_EN? PP3V3S3_EN is a typo of P3V3S3_EN, which is a signal that turns on the PP3V3_S3 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green Light But Won't turn on
threads.message:
The logic board looks pretty clean, however, wont turn on.


<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 8.56V
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 5V
** <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> - 0V - No short to ground
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> - 0V 
<CHIP>U7100</CHIP> = 17/18 - 4Ohms
               27/28 - 20Ohms

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green Light But Won't turn on
threads.message:
Try first to start in SMC bypass, just in case.
Be sure to use original Magsafe 2 charger; better 60/85W for test.
Also post <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> levels.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green Light But Won't turn on
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> = 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> = 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 3.4v

I forgot to mention: <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> / <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> cycling 0 to 2.7 - no short to ground.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green Light But Won't turn on
threads.message: Does CPU VCore pulse as well?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green Light But Won't turn on
threads.message:
Then all S3 voltages should pulse too.
Check if <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> pulses; if yes, all S0 voltages (maybe not CPU VCORE) should also pulse.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green Light But Won't turn on
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green Light But Won't turn on
threads.message: I tried SMC bypass the fan spins and stop.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green Light But Won't turn on
threads.message:
Check if all voltages from page 58 try to appear.
Also test the MLB alone, disconnecting LIO flex.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green Light But Won't turn on
threads.message:
<CHIP>U8010</CHIP>
PIN 2/4 = 3.3V
      6 = 0V (<SIGNAL>PP3V3S3_EN</SIGNAL>)

<CHIP>U8000</CHIP>
PIN 2/4 = 3.3V
    1/3/6 = 0V

<CHIP>U8020</CHIP>
PIN 2/4 = 3.3v
PIN 1/3 = 3.3v
PIN 6 = 3.3v


<CHIP>U8050</CHIP>
PIN 2/4 = 3.3v
    1/3/6 = 0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green Light But Won't turn on
threads.message:
"6 = 0V (<SIGNAL>PP3V3S3_EN</SIGNAL>)"
Doesn't pulse high?
It should, when <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulses; output pins must pulse too, check for short.
Check the same on all these chips.

"Also test the MLB alone, disconnecting LIO flex."

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green Light But Won't turn on
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> = Pulsing 0 to 0.36V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3S3_EN</SIGNAL> = Pulsing 0 to 0.200V and 0.689 and 1.229 and 2.4V and Back to Zero.

Tested without LIO FLEX as well.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green Light But Won't turn on
threads.message: Inspect near <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> for corroded resistors/probe points. Might not be a bad idea to test with a new BIOS as well. Keep old one do not lose it!
